repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem
The cancel function returned by `vim.lsp.buf_request` tries to cancel all the requests, including those that have already been completed, causing "Cannot find request with id ... whilst attempting to cancel" errors to be logged when it is called.

## Solution
Only cancel the requests that are present in `client.requests`.

Resolves #33074

comment_data.body:
There are other calls to `client:cancel_request()` which perhaps should also make this check.  https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/96a0e5f265d11e7913ce71a3a1981b267bda79e5/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/semantic_tokens.lua#L277

That raises the question, should `client:cancel_request` do the check itself? That might violate the spirit of the warning, idk. @lewis6991 ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1313,7 +1313,9 @@ function lsp.buf_request(bufnr, method, params, handler, on_unsupported)
   local function _cancel_all_requests()
     for client_id, request_id in pairs(client_request_ids) do
       local client = all_clients[client_id]
-      client:cancel_request(request_id)
+      if client.requests[request_id] then
+        client:cancel_request(request_id)

comment_data.body:
At least for me it happens exactly there:
```
        ...uilds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua:622: in function '_process_request'
        ...uilds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua:802: in function 'cancel_request'
        .../nvim/builds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua:1315: in function 'cb'
```

comment_data.body: I think it's probably better to have good hygiene of request cancel callers. Code that cancels completed requests could be an indication of other problems.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+        client:cancel_request(request_id)

comment_data.body:
> I think it's probably better to have good hygiene of request cancel callers. Code that cancels completed requests could be an indication of other problems.

Could you provide an example of such filtering (callbacks returned by `lsp.buf_request_all`) on the user side if it is possible?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1313,7 +1313,9 @@ function lsp.buf_request(bufnr, method, params, handler, on_unsupported)
   local function _cancel_all_requests()
     for client_id, request_id in pairs(client_request_ids) do
       local client = all_clients[client_id]
-      client:cancel_request(request_id)
+      if client.requests[request_id] then
+        client:cancel_request(request_id)

comment_data.body:
@przepompownia With `buf_request_all` doing any user-side filtering is basically impossible because you don't get given the underlying request ids - all you have is the cancel function. With `buf_request` you do get that, but because the request id isn't passed as a parameter to the handler callback you can't match completed requests to request ids, and so the only real way to avoid the error is to do `if client.requests[request_id] ...` for each request. But also `buf_request` is private/deprecated.

Therefore I think it makes more sense to have the returned cancel functions only cancel inflight requests. For both functions, there is no other way to prevent the cancel function generating those warnings, and for `buf_request_all`, there is no workaround for cancelling the requests without warning at all.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

   local function _cancel_all_requests()
     for client_id, request_id in pairs(client_request_ids) do
       local client = all_clients[client_id]
-      client:cancel_request(request_id)
+      if client.requests[request_id] then
+        client:cancel_request(request_id)

comment_data.body: @justinmk I can look through the other uses of `cancel_request` and add fixes for them here, or should I make a separate PR? The fix I sent above would be one of those.

> At least for me it happens exactly there:
> 
> ```
>         ...uilds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua:622: in function '_process_request'
>         ...uilds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua:802: in function 'cancel_request'
>         .../nvim/builds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua:1315: in function 'cb'
> ```

@przepompownia Are you sure you've applied the fix from this PR? Those line numbers match the latest commit on `master`, but don't make sense on this branch. And if I look at `master`, the error appears to be coming from the `buf_request` cancel function, which is what this PR is supposed to fix, not from semantic tokens.

> @przepompownia Are you sure you've applied the fix from this PR? 

Yes. My logs are related to using callbacks returned by `buf_request_all` with `completionItem/resolve` - not related to semantic tokens.

comment_data.body:
I mean the original fix in this PR fixing `buf_request` - i.e. 8531d79e4ad90af09d3cd966601ed7481d4f0b4d, not the change from my https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34105#issuecomment-2899576715 above fixing the warning coming from semantic tokens. Because the traceback has `lua/vim/lsp.lua:1315`, but line 1315 is not a call to `cancel_request` on this branch (it's `local client = all_clients[request_id]`). Line 1315 is only the `cancel_request` call on `master`, without 8531d79e4ad90af09d3cd966601ed7481d4f0b4d applied.

Edit: actually now that I think about it, the line number differences might be because of the traceback logging you've added. But in that case I really don't understand why the errors are still showing up, because in `_process_request` the error is **only** logged if `self.requests[id]` is `nil` and my change explicitly skips calling `cancel_request` if `client.requests[request_id]` is `nil`.

comment_regular_data.body:
@AThePeanut4 thank you for investigating. It's very possible that this condition can reduce the amount of such calls (and then logs about). On the other side I still catch similar logs:
```
[ERROR][2025-05-21 12:05:12] ...uilds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua:619    "LSP[null-ls]"  "Cannot find request with id 7 whilst attempting to cancel"
```

I suspected triggering such case after my `completionItem/resolve` calls, but after adding traceback to logs it turns that the first log comes from semantic tokens: 
```
[ERROR][2025-05-21 12:26:14] ...uilds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua:619    "LSP[lua_ls]"   "Cannot find request with id 158 whilst attempting to cancel: traceback: stack traceback:\n\t...uilds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua:621: in function '_process_request'\n\t...uilds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/client.lua:796: in function 'cancel_request'\n\t...m-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/semantic_tokens.lua:276: in function 'send_request'\n\t...m-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/semantic_tokens.lua:568: in function ''\n\tvim/_editor.lua: in function ''\n\tvim/_editor.lua: in function <vim/_editor.lua:0>"
```

@przepompownia It's a bit of a stab in the dark, but does this perhaps fix your issue?
```diff
diff --git a/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/semantic_tokens.lua b/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/semantic_tokens.lua
index 5f60b732de..f16e5c0d16 100644
--- a/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/semantic_tokens.lua
+++ b/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/semantic_tokens.lua
@@ -93,9 +93,9 @@ end
 ---@param data integer[]
 ---@param bufnr integer
 ---@param client vim.lsp.Client
----@param request STActiveRequest
+---@param version integer
 ---@return STTokenRange[]
-local function tokens_to_ranges(data, bufnr, client, request)
+local function tokens_to_ranges(data, bufnr, client, version)
   local legend = client.server_capabilities.semanticTokensProvider.legend
   local token_types = legend.tokenTypes
   local token_modifiers = legend.tokenModifiers
@@ -119,7 +119,7 @@ local function tokens_to_ranges(data, bufnr, client, request)
         vim.schedule(function()
           coroutine.resume(co, util.buf_versions[bufnr])
         end)
-        if request.version ~= coroutine.yield() then
+        if version ~= coroutine.yield() then
           -- request became stale since the last time the coroutine ran.
           -- abandon it by yielding without a way to resume
           coroutine.yield()
@@ -299,8 +299,9 @@ function STHighlighter:send_request()
           return
         end
 
+        highlighter.client_state[c.id].active_request = {}
+
         if err or not response then
-          highlighter.client_state[c.id].active_request = {}
           return
         end
 
@@ -334,12 +335,12 @@ function STHighlighter:process_response(response, client, version)
     return
   end
 
-  -- ignore stale responses
-  if state.active_request.version and version ~= state.active_request.version then
+  if not api.nvim_buf_is_valid(self.bufnr) then
     return
   end
 
-  if not api.nvim_buf_is_valid(self.bufnr) then
+  -- ignore stale responses
+  if version ~= util.buf_versions[self.bufnr] then
     return
   end
 
@@ -369,10 +370,7 @@ function STHighlighter:process_response(response, client, version)
 
   -- convert token list to highlight ranges
   -- this could yield and run over multiple event loop iterations
-  local highlights = tokens_to_ranges(tokens, self.bufnr, client, state.active_request)
-
-  -- reset active request
-  state.active_request = {}
+  local highlights = tokens_to_ranges(tokens, self.bufnr, client, version)
 
   -- update the state with the new results
   local current_result = state.current_result
```

As I understand: when a new semantic token request is sent, the `state.active_request` is cancelled if it is out of date. So `active_request` is meant to contain the current in-flight request, and should be reset as soon as a response is received to prevent a completed request from being cancelled and causing the error log. But the `active_request` is only reset inside of `STHighlighter:process_response` (which is called by the response handler) **after** `tokens_to_ranges` runs - and `tokens_to_ranges` is an async function which yields every 5ms. So if a new semantic token request is triggered before `tokens_to_ranges` completes, then the `active_request` will not have been reset and it will be cancelled even though it has already completed.

The net effect of the changes above is that I've moved the `state.active_request = {}` line all the way up to be directly in the response handler, before `STHighlighter:process_response` is called. That ensures that `active_request` never refers to a request that has already completed.
Even with the above patch I still get `...m/builds/from-src/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/log.lua:149 "LSP[phpactor]" "Cannot find request with id 9 whilst attempting to cancel"`.
@przepompownia Hmm... if you add tracebacks to the log message like you did before, is it still coming from the same place (i.e. semantic tokens)?

title: fix(lsp): avoid cancelling completed requests in `vim.lsp.buf_request`
